One step synthesis of rGO-Ni3S2 nano-cubes composite for high-performance supercapacitor electrodes

sections.heading: Abdolhamid Namdarian a, Amin Goljanian Tabrizi a, Andino Maseleno b,

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Supercapacitor
Graphene
Nickel sulfide
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: Khaled.mohammadi89 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijhydene.2018.07.178 0360-3199/© 2018 Hydrogen Energy Publicati
a b s t r a c t
In the last decade, supercapacitors possessing high power density and cyclic stability have
attracted great interests in various applications. Graphene-based composite electrodes are
known as a promising candidate for supercapacitors due to synergistic effects. For the first
time, in this work, we develop a simple one-step hydrothermal synthesis of graphene
wrapped Ni3S2 nanocubes (rGO-Ni3S2) composite for high-performance and low-cost supercapacitor electrodes. The rGO-Ni3S2 electrode exhibits an ultrahigh specific capacity of 616 C g 1 at the current density of 1 A g 1 with excellent cycling durability of 92.7% after
5000 cycles, which is much better when compared with the counterpart without graphene
(pure Ni3S2). We attribute the remarkable performance of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode to the synergistic effects of the graphene as the conductive support and Ni3S2 cubics as the pseudocapacitive material. This work constitutes a step forward towards the development
of low-cost and high-performance supercapacitors for the next generation of portable
electronics.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Ecological concerns and consequently the increasing demand
for clean energy have greatly stimulated scientists to research
on the development of new environmentally friendly and low-
cost energy storage and conversion systems [1e3]. Super-
capacitors, as a bridge between high power electrolytic ca-
pacitors and high energy batteries, have attracted more and
@gmail.com (A. Mohamm
ons LLC. Published by Els
more attention owning to their higher specific capacitances
than electrolytic capacitors, faster recharge capability and
longer cycle stability than batteries [4e6]. In general, two
different charge storage mechanisms are known for super-
capacitors: fast surface redox process for pseudocapacitors
and non-Faradaic mechanism for electrical double layer ca-
pacitors (EDLC) [7,8]. In the former, the charge storage results
from fast faradaic redox reactions at the electrode/electrolyte
interface. While in the latter, the charge storage arises from

evier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Scheme 1 e Illustration of the formation process of rGO-
Ni3S2 nanocubes.
the charge accumulation at the surface of the electrode.
Because of the presence of the Faradaic process, the pseudo-
capacitors usually deliver a higher specific capacitances than
EDLCs [9e11].
Metal sulfides, a new kind of electrodematerial with higher
electrochemical activity andmore electrical conductivity than
that of the corresponding metal oxides, have attracted great
attention [12e14]. Nickel sulfides are the potential candidates
which are synthesized in various nanostructures. However, in
the supercapacitor applications, the poor conductivity and
pulverization of pure nickel sulfides during electrochemical
testing still remain, which decrease cyclic stability and rate
performance. An effective strategy to overcome these draw-
backs is combining of nickel sulfides with a highly stable and
conductive carbonmaterial as a substrate for supporting them
in the form of composite material [14].
Xuewu Ou et al. reported a two-step procedure for the
fabrication of hollow Ni3S2 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide (rGO). In which, in the first step, they prepared
droplet-shape nickel metal nanoparticles on rGO, and in the
second step, employed a sulfidation process to synthesize the
final Ni3S2/rGO composite. The Ni3S2/rGO showed a specific capacitance of 1015.6 F g 1 (457 C g 1) at a current density of 1 A g 1 [15]. Dai et al. prepared Ni3S2 nanoparticles with a 10e80 nm diameter on a multiwalled carbon nanotubes
(MWCNTs) by using a glucose-assisted method. The composite electrode delivered a specific capacitance of 1024 F g 1 (461 C g 1) at a current density of 0.8 A g 1 [16]. XuewuOu et al. developed a direct method to prepare Ni3S2 nanoplatelets on graphene surface through H2 reduction of NiSO4ehydrazine complex (NiSO4.3N2H4)/GO. Ni3S2/rGO electrode delivered a specific capacitance of 875.6 F g 1 (394 C g 1) at 1 A g 1 [17]. Hualin Lin et al. successfully reported a two-step process for
the synthesis of graphene-coupled flower-like nickel sulfide
monoliths through an F127-assisted hydrothermal method
followed by high-temperature pyrolysis. The as-prepared
rGO-Ni3S2 electrode showed a high specific capacitance of 1315 F g 1 (631 C g 1) at 1 A g 1 [18]. Zesheng Li et al. prepared graphene nanosheets/nickel sulfide nanoparticles (GNs/Ni3S2) electrode in high-temperature by a quasi-chemical vapor
deposition technique. The obtained composite showed a specific capacitance of 652.5 F g 1 (261 C g 1) at 1 A g 1 with cyclic stability of 93% after 2000 cycles [19]. Zhang et al. syn-
thesized a hybrid composite of Ni3S2 nanosheets with 3D rGO on Ni foam via two steps of electrodeposition method and
high-temperature post-annealing under argon atmosphere With a high specific capacitance of 1886 F g 1 (754.4 C g 1) at 1.0 A g 1 [20]. In most articles reportedmetal sulfide/graphene composites, the synthesis process is based on the multi-step
procedure containing preparation of precursors and sulfida-
tion of them, or complex and low yield CVD methods [21e23].
Complex, template-assistance and multi-step synthetic pro-
cedure limits the development of metal sulfide/graphene
composites. Therefore, one step, facile, template-free and
low-cost synthesis which leads to unique morphological fea-
tures is critical for more advancements in metal sulfide/gra-
phene composites electrode materials.
Herein, we report a one-step, facile, template-free and low-
cost approach for the synthesis of rGO-Ni3S2 nanocubes as a high efficient electrode material for supercapacitor
applications. This electrode showed an ultrahigh capacity of 616 C g 1 at 1 A g 1, excellent cycle life and rate capability. This work verifies the potential of the rGO-Ni3S2 composite for developing high-performance energy storage systems.

sections.heading: Material
sections.text:
Pristine graphite, potassium permanganate (KMnO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl), concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2$6H2O), polyvinylidenefluoride (PVDF), N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) and thiourea were all
provided from Merck and used as received.

sections.heading: Preparation of rGO-Ni3S2 nanocubes
sections.text:
Enhanced Hummers method [24,25] was used to synthesis of
GO from natural flake graphite. For the synthesis of rGO-Ni3S2 nanocubes, 1 g of Ni(NO3)2$6H2O was dissolved in 50 mL distilled water, followed by addition of 0.184 g thiourea under
stirring at room temperature. After, 50 mg of GO was
dispersed in the above solution by sonication for 30 min and
then, heated at 160 C in a sealed Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for 18 h. In the end, in order to remove the residuals,
the reaction product was washed several times with ethanol
and DI water (Scheme 1). The preparation of Ni3S2 nanoparticles was also performed without the addition of GO.

sections.heading: Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The electrochemical performance of the prepared electrodes
was examined in a three-electrode cell, consisting of satu-
rated calomel as the reference electrode and platinumwire as
the counter electrode in 6 M KOH. For fabrication of the
working electrode, a slurry of the 15 wt % carbon black, 80 wt
% active material and 5 wt % PVDF in NMP was coated on
1 1 cm Ni foam and dried at 80 C for 10 h. Cyclic voltammetry (CV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS)
and galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) were performed in
the three-electrode cell. The specific capacity (Cm, C g 1) of the electrode was calculated using the following equation [26,27]:
Cm ¼ I Dtm Cg 1
(1)
where Dt is the discharge time (s), m is the total mass of the
active material (g) and I is the discharge current (A).

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text:
The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the
samples were obtained through BET and BJH methods using a
Belsorp-mini II apparatus. Themorphology of the as-prepared
samples was investigated by a Tescan (MIRA3) field-emission
scanning electron microscope. The crystalline nature of the
samples was also evaluated by x-ray diffraction (XRD, D-500)
using Cu-Ka radiation.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Since the morphology of electrodes strongly affects their
performance; Field-emission scanning electron microscopy
(FE-SEM) was used to study the morphology of the as-
synthesized samples. As seen in Fig. 1a, pure Ni3S2 sample consists of agglomerated cubic like particles with a 2e5 mm
size. Fig. 1(bed) show the FESEM images of the rGO-Ni3S2 sample in different magnification. As shown, the Ni3S2 cubes are uniformly distributed on the surface of graphene sheets. It
is inferred that graphene oxide sheets have acted as a sub-
strate for uniform and strongly anchoring of Ni3S2 cubes without agglomeration.
To explore the crystalline structure of the samples, XRD
analyze was performed. Fig. 1e gives the XRD patterns of the
pure Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 samples. Sharp and intense diffraction peaks at 21.7 , 31.2 , 37.8 , 44.4 , 49.7 and 54.1
corresponding to the (101), (110), (003), (202), (113) and (300)
crystal facets of the Ni3S2 phase (JCPDS 044e1418), with no
characteristic peaks related to possible impurities, such as NiS
or NiS2, confirm the good crystallinity of the both samples [20,28]. The smaller size crystallites of the rGO-Ni3S2 sample was also demonstrated from its broader diffraction peaks. The
broad hump appeared between the 2q of 20 e30 in the XRD pattern of rGO-Ni3S2, is attributed to the rGO [15,17,29]. Further investigations on the chemical state of the composite
sample were performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS).
For investigating the elemental composition of the rGO-
Ni3S2 sample, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was carried out. As shown in Fig. 1f, carbon, oxygen, nickel and
sulfur elements are present in the composite. The atomic ratio
of the Ni and S element is calculated to be 3:2, which is in good
agreement with the Ni3S2 stoichiometric ratio.
As a powerful technique for investigating the structures of
carbon-contained nanomaterials [30], Raman spectroscopy
was performed. Fig. S1 represents the Raman spectra of the
GO and rG-Ni3S2 samples. The D-band located at about 1330 cm 1 is related to the disordered structures or defects in the lattice of the carbon materials, while the G-band at about 1575 cm 1 is attributed to the graphitic sp2 carbons [31]. The irregularity and defects of graphene sheets can be determined
by the comparative intensity ratio of the G-band and D-band
(ID/IG) [32,33]. Compared with GO, a higher intensity ratio of the D-band to the G-band for the rGO-Ni3S2 sample represents that (i) GO, through the hydrothermal process, has deeply
reduced and formed amore disordered structure [34], (ii) Ni3S2 cubes have increased the irregularity and defects of graphene
sheets [18].
The more detailed elemental composition of the rGO-Ni3S2 sample was investigated via XPSmeasurement. Deconvoluted
C 1S, Ni 2P and S 2P XPS spectra of the rGO-Ni3S2 sample were shown in Fig. 1g. In the XPS spectrum of Ni 2P, twomain peaks
at the binding energy of 874.5 and 856.4 eV assigned to Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2, respectively, with their satellite peaks appeared at higher values are characteristic of the coexistence of Ni2þ and Ni3þ [35e37]. In the XPS spectrum of C 1S, one sharp peak

sections.text:
t is BJH curve for rGO-Ni3S2 sample.
at 284.4 eV corresponds to the CeC group. For the S 2P spec-
trum, two peaks at 161.8 eV and 162.6 eV can be indexed to
atomic 2P3/2 and P1/2 sulfur in Ni3S2 [18,19].
Fig. 1h shows the nitrogen adsorption/desorption iso-
therms of the Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 samples. As seen, a typical IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop of meso-nanoporous
structures was appeared for rGO-Ni3S2 sample, while bulk sample exhibited a type II isotherm which is belong to non-
porous structures [38,39]. Furthermore, the specific surface area of 23.4 and 62.5 m2 g 1 were calculated from BET analysis for pure Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 samples, respectively. The pore size distribution of the rGO-Ni3S2 sample (inset of Fig. 1h), further confirms the nanoporous structure of the rGO-Ni3S2 sample. The higher specific surface area of rGO-Ni3S2 suggests a much better specific capacity for it [40,41].

sections.heading: Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
To evaluation of the electrochemical properties of the elec-
trodes, CV, GCD and EIS measurements were done in a three-
electrode cell in aqueous 6 M KOH electrolyte. The CV curve of
the pure Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 electrodes at a scan rate of 10 mV s 1 from 0.0 to 0.5 V were illustrated in Fig. 2a. The CV curves exhibit a pair of redox peaks in the potential range of
0.2e0.4 V attributed to the reversible redox reactions of
Ni(II)4Ni(III) [33,42]. When comparing the CV curves, it is
obvious that the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode delivers a higher current densities than pure Ni3S2 electrode. It can be related to the higher electrochemically active surface area and the syner-
getic effects between the rGO and Ni3S2 cubes, suggesting a higher capacity for it. Fig. 2b shows the CVs of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode at different scan rates ranging from 5 to 50 mV s 1.
The shape retention of the CV curves during scan rate

increasing suggests a low internal resistance and good
reversibility of the electrode [43,44].
Another important phenomena that can be extracted from
the CV curves is the reaction kinetics of the electrodes. Ac-
cording to the theory of the voltammetric response, the CV
curve of any electrode can be described as follows [45,46]:

the slope of the plot of log i versus log n as shown in Fig. 2c. It is
well known that in the surface redox reactions and in the EDLCs, the b value is around 1 (I ¼ an, capacitive behavior). While in the diffusion-controlled Faradaic processes, the b value is around 0.5 (I ¼ ssan0.5, battery-type behavior) [12,47]. The range of 0.5e1.0 indicates a “transition” area between the
battery-type materials and the pseudocapacitive materials,
though a clear boundary is not easy to define [48]. As shown in
Fig. 2d, the b values are calculated to be 0.53, 0.54, 0.60, 0.70,
0.82, 0.99, and 0.96 at the potentials of 0.3, 0.325, 0.35, 0.375,
0.4, 0.425, and 0.45 V, respectively. This result confirms that
the kinetics of the electrode possesses both EDLC and surface
redox reactions.

measured from Eq. (4). As shown, by increasing the scan rate,
the capacitive contribution increases.
For investigating specific capacities and rate capability of
the electrodes, GCD measurement was carried out. According
to the GCD curves of the pure Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 electrodes (Fig. 3a) at 1 A g 1, the specific capacity of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode was (616 C g 1) much better than that of pure Ni3S2 (273 C g 1). This result is in good agreement with the CV
behavior of the electrodes. The non-linear profile of the GCD curves corresponds to the Faradaic redox reactions of Ni2þ and Ni3þ couple at the surface of electrodes, as mentioned in CV results (Fig. 3b). High conductivity and low internal resistance
of the electrode, two important factors of high rate super-
capacitors, were demonstrated from very low iR drop in GCD
curves [51,52].
The specific capacity of rGO-Ni3S2 electrode are 616, 492, 422, 377 and 322 C g 1 at 1, 2, 5, 10 and 20 A g 1, respectively. While, the specific capacity s of pure Ni3S2 electrode are 273, 198, 154, 142 and 125 C g 1 at 1, 2, 5, 10 and 20 A g 1, respec-
tively. Fig. 3c shows the specific capacity of the electrodes at
different current densities in order to rate capability com-
parison. As clearly seen, the specific capacity of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode is much higher than that of the pure Ni3S2 electrode, in all current densities. It is acceptable that due to the insuf-
ficient involvement of active material in a redox reaction, the
specific capacity of the electrodes decreases when the current
density increases [2,53]. By maintenance 48% of initial capacity, when current density increases from 1 to 20 A g 1, the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode delivers an excellent rate capability. Table 1 shows the remarkable capacity performance of the rGO-
Fig. 3 e (a) GCD curves of the rGO-Ni3S2 nanocubic and pure Ni3S of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode at various current densities, (c) rate c and rGO-Ni3S2 electrodes, and (f) cycling performance of the rGO
Ni3S2 electrode in comparison with previously reported nickel sulfide electrodes.
The energy density and power density are the two impor-
tant parameters for evaluation overall performance of elec-
trodes. Fig. 3d shows the energy density versus power density
of the pure Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 electrodes in terms of Ragone plot. As seen, the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode exhibits much higher energy densities than pure Ni3S2 electrode. In detail, the energy density of rGO-Ni3S2 was calculated to be 38.2, 30.4, 25.8, 22.8 and 19.5Wh kg 1 at the power density of 0.224, 0.447, 1.11, 2.21 and 4.43 kW kg 1, respectively.
For further understanding the electrochemical behaviors
of Ni3S2 and rGO-Ni3S2 electrodes, EIS was measured at a frequency in the range of 0.01e100 kHz (Fig. 3e). In general, the
Nyquist plot of supercapacitor electrodes consists of different
regions in high, mid and low frequencies [49,54,55]. In high
frequencies, the electrode behaves like a resistor. So, the
intercept of the Nyquist plot on the real axis represents the
equivalent serial resistance (RESR). In mid frequencies, the charge transfer resistance (Rct) and the mass transfer resistance (Zw, Warburg impedance) appear as a semicircle and a steep-slop line, respectively. The charge transfer resistance at
the electrode/electrolyte interface is calculated from the
diameter of the semicircle. In low frequencies, the electrode
behaves as a capacitor and appears as a steeper line (nearly
vertical line for ideal capacitors [56e60]). The lower RESR, Rct and Zw for rGO-Ni3S2 electrode demonstrate its higher conductivity, faster kinetics and lower resistance for diffusion of
electrolyte ions during charge/discharge processes which are
responsible for the much better electrochemical performance
of rGO-Ni3S2 electrode.

cycling stability for this electrode. The results show the su-
perior or comparable performance of optimum structure
developed in this work with other Ni3S2 electrode materials reported before (Table 1).
The outstanding cycling stability, excellent rate capability
and ultrahigh specific capacity of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode can be attributed to the following multiple factors: as shown in
Scheme 2, first, rGO sheets not only act as a 2D supports for
homogenously growth of Ni3S2 cubes but also enhance double-layer capacity by providing high specific surface area
[12].
Second, anchored Ni3S2 cubes not only increase the specific capacity of the composite by faradaic redox reactions but also
effectively enhance the accessible surface area by preventing
the restacking of rGO sheets. Third, the direct contact between
the Ni3S2 cubes and rGO surface facilitates charge transfer [9]. These attractive results develop the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode as a high-performance electrochemical energy storage device for
supercapacitor applications.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we have for the first time developed a facile one-
step method to synthesize uniform Ni3S2 cubs homogeneously anchored on the surface graphene sheets as electrode
for electrochemical capacitors. The rGO-Ni3S2 electrode exhibits enhanced electrochemical performance with a high specific capacity of 616 C g 1 at a current density of 1 A g 1 and an excellent (~93%) rate capability. The synergetic effects
among the rGO and Ni3S2 components make this composite a promising electrode material for energy storage device. This
study sheds a new light into the fabrication of low-cost metal
sulfide hybrid electrodeswhich can bewidely used in different
applications including biosensors, gas sensors, catalysis, Li-
ion batteries, and other electronic devices.

metadata.abstractText: In the last decade, supercapacitors possessing high power density and cyclic stability have attracted great interests in various applications. Graphene-based composite electrodes are known as a promising candidate for supercapacitors due to synergistic effects. For the first time, in this work, we develop a simple one-step hydrothermal synthesis of graphene wrapped Ni3S2 nanocubes (rGO-Ni3S2) composite for high-performance and low-cost supercapacitor electrodes. The rGO-Ni3S2 electrode exhibits an ultrahigh specific capacity of 616 C g 1 at the current density of 1 A g 1 with excellent cycling durability of 92.7% after 5000 cycles, which is much better when compared with the counterpart without graphene (pure Ni3S2). We attribute the remarkable performance of the rGO-Ni3S2 electrode to the synergistic effects of the graphene as the conductive support and Ni3S2 cubics as the pseudocapacitive material. This work constitutes a step forward towards the development of low-cost and high-performance supercapacitors for the next generation of portable
